The evidence concerning the role of lifestyle changes and interventions in the reduction of CVD is rather limited. It remains only to assess which of these interventions will reduce the risk of heart disease and to do so. There have been multiple surveys in recent years regarding the effectiveness of preventive lifestyle interventions. Although most studies are of low methodological quality, all of them have shown that interventions that are aimed at weight management or physical activity are more effective than no intervention. Some studies did not achieve results at all. Other evaluations have provided little to no improvement in blood pressure during a particular period of time. In view of poor quality studies, it is not enough to set up an intervention. The effectiveness of lifestyle interventions needs to be evaluated, whether this involves randomisation, assessing individual differences, monitoring outcomes after intervention and, in the case of obesity in particular, the benefits of individual lifestyle interventions.
There has also been conflicting evidence linking a good lifestyle to reduced risk of heart disease. It has been shown that high-fat, high-salt meals, unhealthy diet, physical inactivity, being overweight, smoking, and alcohol consumption all increase the risk of heart-related events. There is also insufficient evidence on how exercise and physical activity affect the risk of CVD. Some studies have shown that it can be beneficial for maintaining long-term cardiovascular health. There have also been several reviews and meta-analyses of lifestyle interventions and cardiovascular events. For example, exercise alone can have a protective effect in relation to risk of heart-related events, but the effects differ from one individual on another. It is likely that the protective effect of exercise may not be completely neutralised by physical activity over long periods. Therefore, the evidence is limited, although a reduction in risk may be beneficial. As for lifestyle factors, physical activity, smoking cessation, controlling for weight, controlling for alcohol intake, and controlling for medical conditions other than smoking, however, may be more useful for reducing a person's risk of CVD.
Dietary and physical activity recommendations
Studies of the effect of a nutritionally adequate diet, physical activity, exercise and/or smoking cessation have provided limited evidence regarding the relationship between nutrition and CVD. A large number of randomised controlled trials reported reduced risk of CVD if an overweight or obese person followed an adequate diet and/or lifestyle, but there is no evidence of systematic reviews and meta-analyses of health interventions focusing on a large and robust population. In the case of a low-fat, low-cholesterol diet, for example, this would produce an adverse effect. Most studies have been cross-sectional.
One study from Finland compared a high-fat, low-cholesterol diet with a low-fat, low-cholesterol diet. It reported a significant reduction in risk of incident CHD and death, but the effect was not as large as some other studies, and the effect was only marginally beneficial. Most of the nutrition recommendations on diet and lifestyle were based on some kind of diet, for example a vegetarian diet and consumption of fruit and vegetables. These recommendations still provide limited evidence regarding a diet that is healthy for CHD.
The recommendations for physical activity, on the other hand, do not provide much information. These recommendations, as used for health promotion and disease prevention, may represent the best approach regarding physical activity. The guidelines are for CVD prevention and management in primary care settings, not at the individual level. They describe a list of potential interventions in primary care settings and are intended to be used by primary care professionals in primary care settings.
What is the current NICE guideline for CVD prevention in primary care settings?
The current NICE guideline for CVD prevention in primary care settings is a 5 part model showing two components. The first part focuses on maintaining a healthy eating pattern and is applicable to primary care settings. The second half of the guide covers the most commonly used risk factors for CVD development in primary care. As its aim is to be used by primary care professionals, the guidelines are expected to be able to be used by primary care doctors.
What is the recommended approach to prevent new CVD cases in primary care settings?
As the population of primary care doctors is ageing rapidly compared to the general population. There is a need for routine interventions, in particular targeting cardiovascular risk factors, that are used as prevention strategies in primary care settings in the UK. To accomplish this they should firstly be able to take into account the most common causes of CVD in the general population and make recommendations for prevention for the general population.
The recommendations are based on the use the four components of the model in the NHS. In primary care settings they focus on lifestyle interventions. Lifestyle interventions include:
- Lifestyle change: Reducing the risk factor of CVD, i.e. smoking, eating a healthy diet, and stress-management;
- Reducing the risk factors of CVD, i.e. obesity, type II diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidemia, and smoking.
- Reducing the risk factors for death and the overall health care spend which includes reducing the risk factors of smoking (e.g. smoking cessation is one of the main objectives of the NHS).
- Promoting a healthy weight, and reducing the risk factors of dyslipidemia, a lipid-lowering therapy to prevent CVD or other related health problems.
- Reducing the risk of smoking (e.g. through changing your behaviour to not smoke – e-cigarettes and e-liquid)
- Reducing the risk of diabetes (eating a healthy diet and increasing physical activity)
- Reducing the risk of hypertension (high blood pressure)
- Reducing the risk of dyslipidemia (high cholesterol and/or triglycerides)
- Reducing the risk of smoking and the physical activity related to it.
What are the main points to remember when taking a new heart disease preventative measures in primary care settings?
The key points of taking a new heart disease preventive measures in primary care settings are mainly (in order to facilitate communication and cooperation at the general practice level):
- Having a discussion about the most common risk factors for CVD
- Sharing the most important findings around CVD risks (with the client first)
- Emphasising preventive lifestyle actions, together with the results and treatment of the disease
- Setting realistic goals for the patient
- Agreeing on an action plan for each new action. Discussations are often more effective when the patient is more positive with regards to their role in the prevention
- Having the role of the health care professional/doctor informed of whether the patient wishes to take a new heart disease preventive measures in the NHS.

Given that John is a 70-year-old Chinese man with a BMI of 30, blood pressure of 114/61 mmHg, total cholesterol of 6.7 mmol/L, HDL cholesterol of 1.0 mmol/L, currently smokes, does not have diabetes, and has a family history of CVD, what are the NICE guidelines for CVD prevention for him? There is very little debate on the importance of maintaining these types of lifestyle behaviours which are associated with the prevention of CVD.
The focus of the guidance under the NICE guidance includes lifestyle modification in both the prevention and treatment of CVD. This is underpinned by three elements: (a) reducing LDL cholesterol; (b) decreasing the risk of developing heart disease; and (c) having a healthy lifestyle free of risk factors. However, a major area of debate is the role of physical activity on reducing CVD. There is a great deal of literature now supporting the potential of low to moderate level physical activity to reduce the severity of CVD, reduce cardiovascular risk, and even reduce the incidence of cardiovascular events and death. This makes it a particularly relevant exercise regime for people with CVD and their family members as well as all those who wish to improve their chances of living healthy longer. It is likely, however, that a healthy lifestyle includes not only regular moderate to vigorous activity, but also other, less intense activities.
There is now a wealth of evidence supporting the beneficial effect of physical activity on CVD prevention. A good exercise programme can have important beneficial effects on CVD risk factors. However, when implemented appropriately and in the context of risk factors, physical activity alone is able to reduce the risk to a point where exercise and CVD prevention make sense.
There has been some debate about the timing of physical activity in relation to CVD prevention. With only very few people showing the significant improvement in CVD risk factors in previous life-time trials following vigorous exercise over gentle activity, there is considerable concern about the timing of physical activity. This is because the evidence is not conclusive on the optimum timing of exercise. The evidence is also conflicting about the timing, intensity and duration of activity, with the most common explanation being that intensity and duration should be between the training sessions.
This means that the benefits of physical activity are likely to vary over time. In principle there is little difference between moderate to vigorous physical activity and less vigorous physical activity and yet there is considerable evidence supporting the benefit of greater intensity over a more gentle duration.
As part of their exercise guidance the NICE guidelines for CVD prevention also includes recommendations for the implementation of personalised exercise interventions. A number of studies suggest increasing physical activity, particularly if the exercise is of high intensity, decreases the risk of CVD, irrespective of type of lifestyle.
The evidence for the efficacy of individual components of physical activity to reduce CVD risk for people with CVD has been mixed. There is strong evidence that physical activity is important in the general public at risk for developing heart disease. In the current analysis of the current evidence it was not clear if physical activity or physical exercise was more important in reducing heart disease risk, however, there was a significant effect of physical activity upon CVD risk.
There is also concern that the benefits of health intervention appear to be dependent on the severity of CVD for the individuals participating in the intervention program. For example, it is not clear whether the benefits of high intensity exercise are more important for individuals with worse chronic disease rather than more mild CVD than better chronic disease. Therefore, this risk has often come in at a late stage in the intervention programme.
To date, no information has been published of the specific effects of physical activity on people with CVD. There is also conflicting evidence as to whether the benefits are sustained after the intervention program.
The current evidence for the benefits of exercise for people with CVD is somewhat conflicting at present. Although several observational studies suggest that exercise is beneficial for individuals with CVD, little is known about the benefits of physical exercise for individuals without CVD. This is because there are few epidemiological studies which follow subjects for long enough to determine whether exercise is beneficial in people with CVD.
There is some evidence of the benefits of low to moderate intensity physical activity for individuals with CVD, but this evidence of benefit needs to be examined more closely. This could have major implications for CVD prevention. These include an improvement in clinical outcomes (with potential benefits in CVD management and patient outcomes such as quality of life, smoking cessation and the effects of the treatment), as well as positive economic implications as exercise has been shown to help with weight loss, blood pressure control and the management of other conditions such as diabetes and heart disease.
Physical activity guidelines for CVD should therefore provide individuals with CVD with the opportunity to exercise in the context of high to moderate intensity or at a low intensity of exercise, and to maintain the recommended levels of activity and duration and intensity of exercise in a programme which addresses health risk factors.
This strategy would help individuals and families at increased risk for CVD and their families to reduce the risk.

According to the “National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES 5) 2011-2012,” “physical inactivity was the greatest risk factor for heart disease.” People who were not physically active had a greater chance of dying early than exercising more regularly (7.7 versus 3.1 deaths per 100,000 person-years, P =.001).
However, smoking is associated with an increased risk of heart disease due to a number of potentially modifiable factors. When these factors are taken together, the potential for a high risk of heart disease is increased. This is an unfortunate reality for many people: it means that their risk of early death is greater than in people who are not exposed to such factors. Health is associated with the life span (the length of a person’s life) and of the body or organ systems (your body). The 2012 NICE Guidelines provide evidence-based guidelines for the prevention of CVD, which are published elsewhere  and are available on the Department of Health and Social Services website  and can be accessed through the NHS website. However, they do not provide detailed guidance for cardiovascular disease prevention which is not included in the NICE guidelines. As there is an extremely low prevalence of cardiovascular disease in Japan, for the purposes of this paper, the focus will be on NICE guidelines from the 'European Institute of Diabetes and Obesity' report 1. It is evident in the report that the most common age-specific CVDs are ischemic stroke with 28%, coronary heart disease with 16%, myocardial infarction with 12%, and hypertensive heart disease (HTD) with 10%. A 2015 study  provides evidence which could add to the body of evidence by providing an estimate of the burden of CVDs in Japan, using data from Japan's population-based community-based cohort, the Baka Cohort, located in Kagoshima Prefecture. In this report, the findings of the study do not provide detailed information on the results of the NICE guidelines, particularly in terms of CVD. However, both the NICE guidelines  and the Baka Cohort  provide evidence-based recommendations for the prevention of CVD and are published elsewhere, highlighting evidence on the most appropriate clinical trial strategies for CVD treatment. To improve overall UK health status, as outlined in the 2009 Health Improvement Plan 1,2 we should improve the knowledge of what types of interventions are most effective and how the best methods and treatments for CVD can be optimized and delivered by the health care service providers. The aim of this paper is to discuss whether there is a need for community-based trials in the prevention of CVD and the use of randomized clinical trials. In this regard, the review identifies examples of community-based trials on the prevention of CVD and demonstrates the need to improve the approach for these trials through the identification of relevant public health programmes that directly treat CVD and which are cost-effective, and which follow clearly laid out research protocols, and evidence-based guidelines to guide the study design, sample selection and risk assessment. An examination of how the study design can be used to increase the coverage of evidence based guidelines and ensure the prevention of CVD and the use of a 'cluster randomized controlled trial' (MRCT.) to identify whether there is sufficient evidence for evidence-based guidelines to produce an improvement. Key areas investigated include: - • the impact of community-based trials in CVD prevention and the use of randomisation to investigate health outcomes,  - • the identification of key clinical risk factors in which the benefit of community based trials would be greatest - and - • the development and implementation of interventions to promote cardiovascular health in order to improve overall UK health status.

Heart disease is more than just a blockage. CHD involves a number of factors, not just heart attacks but heart diseases that cause a lot of problems in a person’s life, such as heart attack and stroke:
- the risk factors for these complications: smoking, high blood pressure (hypertension), high cholesterol, high blood sugar, unhealthy eating habits and some types of cancer.

- keeping to a healthy diet
- taking regular medicines as prescribed by your doctor
- to manage your family medical history
- taking medicines when prescribed

It occurs when the electrical signal that controls the heartbeat is lost and the heart contracts unusually too quickly. - The diet, which affects the metabolism: Diets with high calories and low fibre can be hard to follow. In particular, people with obesity who consume less fibre are likely to gain weight. They also have a lower percentage of muscle mass. People with diabetes also have a lower muscle mass and a lower percentage of body fat. These factors put a particular emphasis on fibre.
- The type of food: For both types of body weight management, people with diabetes should eat more fiber. However, there is no definitive evidence that the type of food consumed will affect weight gain in your blood. If you choose a whole grain breakfast or whole milk cereal, they both seem to be less detrimental to weight gain than refined grains.
- The alcohol: You should exercise a little more, eat less if you drink more, and limit the amount of alcohol you drink. People who are diabetic should limit their alcohol intake and, for those who want to have one, limit it to 1-2 glasses a week.
- Lifestyle modifications, based on the diet recommendations: The weight management advice will be different for people with diabetes and those without, and the type of diet must be based on the individual. A healthy, balanced diet should include protein, carbohydrates, and fats that are good for the body and, especially, should be high quality and that promotes good health. There are also some other things you should add to your list, such as low-fat dairy products and lots of vitamin water.

It is thought that the high intensity training, which is often advocated by the diabetes experts, may only worsen the condition. If you have diabetes or want to exercise, it wouldn't hurt to practice a series of five minutes of brisk walking in a day.

A review of NICE guidelines for cardiovascular disease risk assessment for people aged 30 years or older
Cardiac disease risk assessment guidelines are a recommendation for people aged 30 years or older. The recommendations from NICE (National Institute for Health and Care Excellence) suggest that people aged 30 years or older should be tested for heart disease. They recommend that people aged 30 years are tested for diabetes, high cholesterol, coronary heart disease, heart failure, stroke, atrial fibrillation, and other cardiovascular disease risk factors. These measurements help healthcare professionals understand the overall risk of cardiovascular disease and develop effective prevention strategies.
What is the goal of the NICE guidelines?
The NICE guidelines emphasize the importance of screening for heart disease risk factors in people aged 30 years or older. These risk factors include high blood pressure, cholesterol levels, diabetes, and a family history of heart disease. Screening provides the opportunity for early detection and management of these conditions, ultimately reducing the risk of future cardiovascular events.
The recommended screening test for cardiovascular disease risk assessment includes measuring:
● Total Cholesterol: Ideally, healthcare professionals measure total cholesterol using a 120kPa sphygmomanometer cuff. This measurement indicates the overall level of cholesterol in the body, which can help determine the risk of heart disease. Ideally, healthcare professionals adjust the measurements to a normal range (0-80) as indicated by NICE guidelines.
● Triglyceride Level: Another possible cardiac risk factor is triglycerides, commonly measured by meters. This measurement indicates the amount of fat in the blood that can act as a marker of heart disease risk. High triglycerides can raise the risk of heart disease, so healthcare professionals typically monitor triglycerides to determine the need for further testing.
● Total LDL Cholesterol Level: LDL cholesterol, known as bad cholesterol, is considered high in this type of risk factor, as high LDL cholesterol levels can increase the risk of cardiovascular disease.
● HDL Cholesterol Concentration: A higher level of HDL cholesterol indicates higher-density lipoprotein cholesterol, which aids in maintaining good heart health. This measurement also helps identify the individuals with the lowest LDL cholesterol levels.
● Fasting Blood Glucose Level: Monitoring fasting blood glucose level is particularly important for individuals whose blood glucose levels remain persistently high. It is crucial to regularly measure fasting glucose levels to diagnose any potential cardiovascular complications as well as to assess if the patient requires further testing.
How often should a person be tested for cardiovascular disease risk?
Regular and thorough cardiovascular disease risk assessment is crucial for individuals aged 40 or older. It is recommended that healthcare professionals follow these guidelines to maintain the best possible cardiovascular health:
● Screening for Cardiovascular Disease Risk: Regular screening for cardiovascular disease risk is important to detect high blood pressure, cholesterol levels, and diabetes in people aged 45 years or older. Healthcare professionals assess these cardiovascular risk factors as part of an overall health evaluation.
● Follow-up Follow-Up: Regular follow-up appointments and regular follow-ups with healthcare professionals are important for evaluating blood pressure, cholesterol levels, and diabetes levels over time. Regular appointments allow the healthcare team to track the progress and adjust prevention strategies as needed.
● Evaluate Smoking: Smoking is a known risk factor for heart disease. Healthcare professionals use questionnaires to check for smoking in people aged 40 or older. This evaluation can help assess the presence and severity of smoking-related health problems or changes over time.
● Use of EKG: EKG (Electrocardiogram) is an important standard for evaluating heart function and detecting changes in heart rhythms. Healthcare professionals use this test frequently to track heart rhythms and detect abnormal cardiac patterns.
● Use of CPT Code: For medical procedures involving instruments or devices, healthcare professionals use the correct clinical procedure code. The correct code for an invasive procedure, for example, a cardiac biopsy, must be obtained after proper documentation with proper reference codes.
By following these guidelines, healthcare professionals can assess and monitor cardiovascular health over time and inform appropriate preventive strategies. The results of the tests play a vital role in identifying and addressing potential complications related to heart disease, including CVD risk assessment and diagnosis.

You might be able to manage your risk of developing coronary heart disease (CHD) by eating a healthy diet. A low SBP/DBP (blood pressure level) and low ejection fraction (EF) is vital for preventing sudden cardiac death. We should be asking people in most cases of cardiac disease to eat a diet rich in whole, fresh plant foods and lower in refined foods and added sugars. However, people with a heart condition should also be aware that there are nutritional implications. For example, the cholesterol in a fat-free diet has been shown to significantly increase the risk of coronary heart disease and other vascular problems (including hardening of the arteries, angina, stroke and heart failure) compared to those who were eating a diet rich in complex carbohydrates. The latest guidelines developed by the National Institute of Clinical Excellence in the UK state that a person should have the following components for each risk category:
- An estimate of the person's risk of developing CVD if the person had a coronary (heart) event at any point in their lifetime: this is also known as the risk factor calculation or Q model.
- The age and gender-specific relative risk of the person having a coronary event at any point in their lifetime: this is also known as the relative risk or Risk Factor Model. These categories are calculated as follows:
- When the average number of years a person is young when a CVD event takes place was used, the relative risk was zero. This means that the risk group of a person at any point in their lifetime was the same.
- If the amount of each risk factor increased significantly over time, the relative risk was increased as well.
- The person's gender-specific risk factor percentage was used: for women, this was the proportion of a person's lifetime risk of a cardiac event that the woman was at a high risk of having: this would be the mean risk factor percentage of males. For both men and women, the percentage of a person's lifetime risk of a cardiovascular event was measured in terms of women's or men's relative risk percentage.
- The number of events as a result of the risk factors above was used as a means of calculating the relative hazard proportion of the person at any point in their lifetime, that is, the proportion of a person's lifetime risk of a cardiac event as a result of the risk factors above
The NICE guidelines for CVD risk management are as follows:
- For the overall risk group (heart disease), any increase in all but the strongest risk factors (that were measured in Q-Model age- and gender-specific ways) was considered a significant increase in the total risk of a cardiac event (that is, a major factor in the woman's relative risk).
- For the person in high risk or poor risk (that were measured in multiple other risk factors, at least two were measured with Q models of higher reliability) or the person in the lower risk, it was considered a significant increase in the total risk of a cardiac event (that at any point in her lifetime was due to the risk factors above).
Please note that these guidelines are not specific to CVD. They are based on an extremely strict, and therefore, highly complex, algorithm that was developed to show the effects of many different risk factor combinations and levels of risk. These individual, risk factor, factors are generally based on one or more evidence lists and recommendations from the American Heart Association (AHA) and American College of Cardiology (ACC). This algorithm may, for example, use information based on the risk factors listed under the individual risk factor, the age and sex category of the person in the first category, and the age and sex category of that one at the time.

With the previous point, it has been established that people with a moderate level of risk should be screened more often. In order to avoid adverse effects, the level of cardiovascular risk is set in the framework established by the NICE in its guidance on screening patients in a timely manner (NICE Guidance 2012). However, since this guidance only applies to individuals with a current assessment, those patients who do not have a disease or condition should be treated for cardiovascular risk. Therefore, we recommend that the following prevention strategies should be considered first:
First, individuals should be screened for early CVD risk in all patients with an annual high risk score (Q1, Q3, Q4), who demonstrate a CVD risk factor above 3 or a family history of CVD. Second, these patients should be screened for CVD risk factors that have been identified. Third, patients with moderate or low cardiovascular risk should be screened for CVD risk factors that are not identified by screening and should be enrolled according to the relevant patient profile. For those patients with a low risk score, screening should be avoided first because people with low cardiac risk are at an increased risk of dying from a cardiac event such as heart attack. For these patients, screening is a good strategy. Finally, patients with moderate or high cardiovascular risk should not be treated. Patients with high cardiovascular risk can have a good long-term prognosis.
The 4-tier prevention approach will be in accordance with an overall goal of lowering the number of adverse cardiometabolic conditions in addition to the number of adverse outcomes, such as coronary heart disease, high blood pressure, stroke, diabetes, cancer, obesity, and pre-existing heart disease, and will be considered among the first-line preventive strategies for CVD.
